Less food and water.

Loss of habitat for fish
and wildlife.

More forest fires occur.

Endangered species
can face extinction.

Erosion of soil.

Health problems from
dust and bad water.

Threats to home and lives
from forest fires.

Anxiety and depression.

Loss of incomes.

Loss of recreational activities.

We now use
127% more water
than we did in 1950!

Most of that water
swirls down the drain.

Using less
adds up!

Turn each card.

Don’t let the water
run while
washing dishes.

Don’t let the water
run continuously while
brushing your teeth.

Use leftover water from
the melted ice in your
glass to water plants.

Only wash full
loads of clothes.

Don’t let water
run to warm up.
Use it lukewarm.

Or collect cooler water
in a bucket for plants
or cleaning or flushing.

Check to see if your
toilet tank is leaking by
placing food dye in the tank
and seeing if it becomes
visible in the bowl.

Don’t flush to
throw away stuff.
Use a trash can.

Wash the car in the grass
instead of the driveway.

Sweep sidewalks instead
of hosing them.

Use mulch or compost
around plants, which
reduces their water needs.

Drought can have
severe effects on
the environment.

Drought is very
bad for
humans too.

and now you have it!

Take this real world and do "Tag It"
to share your message of responsibility.

your new

Are you sure you
want to quit?
